newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian bonds take breather after whippy week.
newsitem.headline: Australian bonds take breather after whippy week.

text.p: *Australian bonds showed modest yield falls in early trading, but interest was thin as the market caught its breath after the whippy price action seen this week.
*Fed's Greenspan to deliver speech at 10.30 a.m. (0030 GMT).
Australian bonds showed modest yield falls in early trading following a rally in U.S. Treasuries, but interest was thin as the market caught its breath after the whippy price action seen this week.

The short end was knocked back on Thursday after Reserve Bank governor Ian Macfarlane made it clear that there would be no further easing in monetary policy this cycle, squeezing out long positions which had been looking for another cut.
"The market's re-positioned for a long period of no policy change. There's little reason to buy or sell the short end now," one trader said.
This was clearly evident in June bill futures, which took 30 minutes before it clocked up it first trade.

Bond yields eased slightly after Thursday's rally in U.S. Treasuries on Thursday, where bargain hunting helped to absorb this week's quarterly refunding supply, particularly in the 10-year part of the curve which saw a record volume.
Early attention will be focussed on a speech by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan in New York at 10.30 a.m. local time (0030 GMT) for any clues on U.S. policy.
But "It's likely to be a non-event for us given Macfarlane has made it clear on our policy stance," one trader added.
The local market's stable stance saw spreads narrow against the dollar bloc, particularly against Canadian debt which was undermined by weakness in the Canadian dollar.
The yield curve continued its flattening trend to test support at 85 basis points on the 3/10-year futures spread.
